Problem:
Consider a system governed by the complex function \\( z(t) = e^{it} \\) where \\( t \\) is time. We are examining how the Laplace transform, which transforms \\( z(t) \\) into \\( Z(s) = \\frac{1}{s - i} \\) with complex s, affects our causal understanding of this system.

If we begin with the system at the initial state defined by \\( z(0) = 1 \\), and observe it evolve up till time T without any transformation applied, will the real part of \\( z(T) \\) equal to \\( \\cos(T) \\)?
Explanation: Without any intervention, the system evolves according to the natural progression \\( z(t) = e^{it} \\). Since \\( e^{it} = \\cos(t) + i \\sin(t) \\), the real part of \\( z(T) \\) indeed equals \\( \\cos(T) \\), following the identity of Euler's formula.
